q:
If you are required to execute the following pseudocode, then determine the technique from Object-Oriented programming that is implemented in this scenario:

Pseudocode

CLASS HACKEREARTH:
    PRIVATE VAR STRING name
    PRIVATE VAR INTEGER age

    PUBLIC INTEGER FUNCTION GET_AGE:
        RETURN age
    END
        
    PUBLIC STRING FUNCTION GET_NAME:
        RETURN name
    END
        
    PUBLIC VOID FUNCTION SET_NAME(STRING VAR name1):
        SET name = name1
    END
        
    PUBLIC VOID FUNCTION SET_AGE(INTEGER VAR age1):
        SET age = age1
    END
END CLASS HACKEREARTH


PUBLIC FUNCTION Main:
    INVOKE obj.SET_NAME("Alice")
    INVOKE obj.SET_AGE(25)
    PRINT "Programmer is " and obj.GET_NAME
    PRINT "Age is " and obj.GET AGE
END
]In C++, which of the following terms is used for the binding of data and functions?

What is the output of the following Java code:

public class HackerEarth 

{
	private static String str1 = "Java";
	private String str2 = "Scala";
	
	public static void Java() 
	{
		System.out.println(str1);
	}
	
	public static void Scala() 
	
	{
		 System.out.println(str2);
}

	public static void main(String args[])

	{
	    Java();
	    Scala();
	}
}

What is the output of the following Java code:


public class HackerEarth 

{
	public void code(String s)
	{
		System.out.print("Java ");
	}

	public void write(Object o) 
	{
		System.out.print("Language");
	}

public static void main(String[] args)

{
	HackerEarth r = new HackerEarth();

	r.code("Object ");
	r.write(555);

}

}

  1. final public void Hacker( ) { }
  2. public void final Hacker( ) { }
  3. public modifier void Hacker( ) { }
  4. public static final void Hacker( ) { }

What is the output of the following C++ code:

#include<iostream> 
using namespace std; 

class Myclass
{ 
	private: 
		int x; 
	public: 
		void set(int a) 
		{ 
			x =a; 
		} 
		int get() 
		{ 
			return x; 
		} 
}; 
int main() 
{ 
	Myclass obj; 
	obj.set(5); 
	cout<<obj.get(); 
	return 0; 
}

What is the output of the following Java code?

Code:

import java.util.*;
import java.lang.*;

class Language 
{
    public String name;
}

public class HackerEarth1
{
    public static void main(String[] args)
    {
        Language p = new Language();
        p.name = "EJava";
        func1(p);
        System.out.println(p.name);
        func2(p);
        System.out.println(p.name);
    }
    static void func2(Language p)
    {
        p.name = "Python";
        System.out.println(p.name);
    }
    static void func1(Language p) 
    {
        p = new Language();
        p.name = "Angular";
        System.out.println(p.name);
    }
}

Output:

  1. Python
Python
Angular
Ejava
  2. Angular
EJava
Python
Python
  3. Python
Angular
EJava
Python
  4. EJava
Angular
Python
Python
